title: 103_hr2609
content: The "Presidential Commission on TV Violence and Children Act" is established due to the findings that violence on television is linked to societal violence, and there is a need to address this issue while preserving freedom of expression. The "Presidential Commission on TV Violence and Children" is established to address the link between television violence and societal violence while preserving freedom of expression. The Commission's duties include investigating and making recommendations on this issue. The Commission is tasked with reviewing findings on television violence's impact, gathering opinions from children, parents, experts, and industry professionals, and presenting comprehensive strategies to mitigate harmful effects while upholding free expression. The Commission, composed of the Surgeon General, the Attorney General, and 26 members appointed by the President, includes individuals from various groups such as broadcast television networks, parents and children, and public health experts studying television violence and crime prevention. The Commission, consisting of the Surgeon General, the Attorney General, and 26 members appointed by the President, includes individuals from different groups such as broadcast television networks, parents and children, public health experts, and education experts studying television violence. Members serve for the life of the Commission without pay, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission members, including federal employees and Members of Congress, cannot receive additional compensation. They will receive travel expenses as per regulations. A majority constitutes a quorum for meetings, with the Surgeon General as chairperson and the Attorney General as vice chairperson. Meetings will be called by the chairperson. SEC. 6. DIRECTOR AND STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Commission, paid at the maximum rate of basic pay for GS-13. Additional staff may be appointed and paid according to civil service laws. Federal agencies may detail personnel upon request. The Commission may request personnel from federal agencies on a reimbursable basis to assist in carrying out its duties under this Act. SEC. 7. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and obtain official data from government agencies to carry out its duties. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and the Commission can use the United States mails and request administrative support services. The Commission can request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services on a reimbursable basis to carry out its responsibilities under this Act. The Commission will submit a final report to the President and Congress within one year of appointment, detailing findings, conclusions, and recommendations to address television violence. The Commission will terminate six months after submitting the report. $1,000,000 is authorized for this Act, and budget compliance is required. Any spending authority authorized by this Act shall be effective only to the extent provided in appropriation Acts.
